column1: The wild boar features prominently in the cultures of Indo-European people
column2: many of which saw the animal as embodying warrior virtues. Cultures throughout Europe and Asia Minor saw the killing of a boar as proof of one's valor and strength. Neolithic hunter gatherers depicted reliefs of ferocious wild boars on their temple pillars at Göbekli Tepe some 11
column3: 600 years ago. Virtually all heroes in Greek mythology fight or kill a boar at one point. The demigod Herakles' third labour involves the capture of the Erymanthian Boar
column4: Theseus slays the wild sow Phaea
column5: and a disguised Odysseus is recognised by his handmaiden Eurycleia by the scars inflicted on him by a boar during a hunt in his youth. To the mythical Hyperboreans
column6: the boar represented spiritual authority. Several Greek myths use the boar as a symbol of darkness
column7: death and winter. One example is the story of the youthful Adonis
column8: who is killed by a boar and is permitted by Zeus to depart from Hades only during the spring and summer period. This theme also occurs in Irish and Egyptian mythology
column9: where the animal is explicitly linked to the month of October

column1: === As a game animal and food source ===
Humans have been hunting boar for millennia
column2: the earliest artistic depictions of such activities dating back to the Upper Paleolithic. The animal was seen as a source of food among the Ancient Greeks
column3: as well as a sporting challenge and source of epic narratives. The Romans inherited this tradition
column4: with one of its first practitioners being Scipio Aemilianus. Boar hunting became particularly popular among the young nobility during the 3rd century BC as preparation for manhood and battle. A typical Roman boar hunting tactic involved surrounding a given area with large nets
column5: then flushing the boar with dogs and immobilizing it with smaller nets. The animal would then be dispatched with a venabulum
column6: a short spear with a crossguard at the base of the blade. More than their Greek predecessors
column7: the Romans extensively took inspiration from boar hunting in their art and sculpture. With the ascension of Constantine the Great
column8: boar hunting took on Christian allegorical themes
column9: with the animal being portrayed as a "black beast" analogous to the dragon of Saint George. Boar hunting continued after the fall of the Western Roman Empire
column10: though the Germanic tribes considered the red deer to be a more noble and worthy quarry. The post-Roman nobility hunted boar as their predecessors did
column11: but primarily as training for battle rather than sport. It was not uncommon for medieval hunters to deliberately hunt boars during the breeding season when the animals were more aggressive. During the Renaissance
column12: when deforestation and the introduction of firearms reduced boar numbers
column13: boar hunting became the sole prerogative of the nobility

column1: Actual attacks on humans are rare
column2: but can be serious
column3: resulting in penetrating injuries to the lower part of the body. They generally occur during the boars' rutting season from November to January
column4: in agricultural areas bordering forests or on paths leading through forests. The animal typically attacks by charging and pointing its tusks towards the intended victim
column5: with most injuries occurring on the thigh region. Once the initial attack is over
column6: the boar steps back
column7: takes position and attacks again if the victim is still moving
column8: only ending once the victim is completely incapacitated.Boar attacks on humans have been documented since the Stone Age
column9: with one of the oldest depictions being a cave painting in Bhimbetaka
column10: India. The Romans and Ancient Greeks wrote of these attacks (Odysseus was wounded by a boar and Adonis was killed by one). A 2012 study compiling recorded attacks from 1825–2012 found accounts of 665 human victims of both wild boars and feral pigs
column11: with the majority (19%) of attacks in the animal's native range occurring in India. Most of the attacks occurred in rural areas during the winter months in non-hunting contexts and were committed by solitary males.
